content:

The Purchaser(s)/Borrower(s) and Seller(s)/Owner(s) acknowledge receipt of a copy of the settlement statement and accept it as a correct representation of the agreement.  
ALLIED TITLE & ESCROW, LLC (“Settlement Agent”) has no liability for matters not appearing of record after the title examination date.  
The parties acknowledge that ALLIED TITLE & ESCROW, LLC, as the title insurance agent, receives a commission on the title insurance premium.

The Seller(s)/Owner(s) confirm there are no unpaid obligations affecting the property other than those shown on the settlement statement.  
They guarantee prompt and full satisfaction of any unpaid liens/bills not listed and indemnify the Settlement Agent from liability.

ALLIED TITLE & ESCROW, LLC does not guarantee the accuracy of third-party information such as:  
- Contract provisions  
- Water/sewer charges  
- Taxes and assessments  
- Loan balances

Parties are responsible for resolving any discrepancies.

ALLIED TITLE & ESCROW, LLC is not liable for notices or violations of:  
- Occupancy  
- Zoning  
- Truth-in-lending  
- Consumer protection regulations  
- Governmental orders

Settlement is not complete until:  
- Certified funds are received and cleared  
- All checks (including assignment of funds) are received and cleared  
- All documents are properly executed and delivered  
- Lender’s requirements are fulfilled  
- Title search is current through recordation

Paulson Law Group PLLC acts as legal counsel to ALLIED TITLE & ESCROW, LLC.  
If an attorney from the firm conducts the settlement, they do not represent either party.  
Any owed legal fees may be disbursed up to 90 days after settlement.

ALLIED TITLE & ESCROW, LLC may make corrections to the settlement statement if:  
- Items are incorrect  
- Collected funds are insufficient  
Parties agree to reimburse any owed amounts and cover related legal fees.

section: 8) CORRECTION AGREEMENT – LIMITED POWER OF ATTORNEY
content:
The parties agree to cooperate in correcting typographical/clerical errors in closing documents.  
ALLIED TITLE & ESCROW, LLC may:  
- Make corrections  
- Initial changes  
- Sign on the parties’ behalf  
Copies of amended documents will be provided.
The parties certify that they are the actual parties to the transaction and that identity representations are accurate.

Any check not cashed within 90 days is subject to:  
- $50.00 administrative fee  
- Additional $50.00 fee every 30 days  
(Fees will not exceed the check amount.)
Purchaser(s) acknowledge receipt of the survey and confirm that all details (e.g., lot lines, easements, encroachments) were explained at settlement.

The Seller must disclose any applicable Homeowner’s or Condominium Associations.  
Failure to do so makes the Seller responsible for associated fees and prorations.

ALLIED TITLE & ESCROW, LLC collects personal info from:  
- Your agent (e.g., name, address, SSN)  
- Transactional sources (e.g., lender, attorney, broker)  
- Public records  
They do not disclose personal info except as permitted by law.  
Access is limited to employees who need it.  
They maintain appropriate physical, electronic, and procedural safeguards.

(Property Address)  
Owned by: (Seller Name)
This affidavit is provided to induce Old Republic National Title Insurance Company to remove exceptions from the lender's title insurance policy for this transaction.

- I/We have owned the property continuously for __________ years.  
- Enjoyment has been peaceable and undisturbed.  
- Title has never been disputed or questioned to my/our knowledge.  
- I/We are not aware of any facts that would raise a dispute over title or possession.
1. No party other than the Seller(s)/Owner(s) is in possession of any part of the property under any unrecorded leases or tenancy.
2. During our ownership, no part of the premises has been conveyed nor any action taken that could change property boundaries.
3. No encroachments have been made on the property by adjoining landowners, and we have not encroached on others' properties.
4. No easements, rights of way, continuous driveway use, or utility access has been allowed or is known to exist adversely over the property.
5. No construction, erection, alteration, or repairs have been made on the property within the past 180 days.  
- No materials have been delivered for which unpaid charges remain.
6. We have no knowledge of any highways, abandoned roads, lanes, cemeteries, springs, streams, rivers, ponds, or lakes on or bordering the property.
7. We are unaware of any unpaid taxes or special assessments not already disclosed in the title insurance binder or attorney's opinion.
8. No violations of covenants, restrictions, agreements, conditions, or zoning ordinances affecting the property have occurred or are known.

section: THE FAQs OF TITLE INSURANCE FOR HOMEOWNERS
content:
A home is the single largest investment most of us will make in our lives.  
To buy with confidence, get **owner's title insurance** — it's the smart way to protect your property from legal and financial claims.  
To help you understand how it works, here are answers to common questions:
A title is your legal ownership right to your property.

A title search is a standard part of the homebuying process conducted to uncover issues that could prevent your right to the property.  
Your closing agent reviews public records to identify any problems or defects that could cause legal issues.
If you're buying a home, title insurance is a policy that protects your investment and property rights.

section: WHY SHOULD I PURCHASE OWNER'S TITLE INSURANCE?
content: Purchasing owner's title insurance is a smart decision because it’s the best way to protect your property from future legal claims.

section: WHAT DOES OWNER'S TITLE INSURANCE COST?
content:
The one-time payment is low relative to the value of your home.  
The typical owner’s title insurance policy costs around **0.5% of the home's purchase price**.

1. **Owner’s Policy**  
Protects your property rights for as long as you or your heirs own the home.
2. **Lender’s Policy**  
Usually required by the lender and protects only the lender’s financial interests.  
The buyer typically pays for this policy, but this varies by location.  
Ask an ALTA member how it’s handled in your area.

Your owner’s insurance policy lasts as long as you or your heirs own your property.  
Your life will change over time, but your peace of mind never will.
You sign the legal documents and receive the keys to your home.

Call Allied: 703-567-7933  
Send title requests to: orders@alliedtitleandescrow.com  
3100 Clarendon Blvd, Ste 630, Arlington, VA 22201-5302  
www.alliedtitleandescrow.com

*This advertising is for informational purposes only.  
Actual coverages and eligibility may vary by company and state.  
For exact terms, conditions, exclusions, and limitations, contact a licensed title insurance company in your area.*

section: 7 REASONS WHY EVERY HOMEBUYER NEEDS OWNER'S TITLE INSURANCE
content:
Buying a home is an exciting and emotional time.  
To help you buy your home with confidence, make sure you get **owner's title insurance**.  
Here’s why it’s so important:

A home is probably the single largest investment you’ll make in your life.  
You insure everything else that’s valuable to you — your life, car, health, pets —  
so why not your home?  
For a **one-time fee**, owner's title insurance protects your **property rights** for as long as  
you or your heirs own your home.

There are many hidden issues that can surface after purchase.  
Owner's title insurance protects you from unforeseen legal and financial problems.
Common unexpected title claims include:
- Outstanding mortgages, judgments, or tax liens from the previous owner  
- Pending legal action against the property  
- Unknown heirs claiming ownership

Owner’s title insurance is a **one-time fee** that is **low relative to the value it provides**.  
It typically costs around **0.5% of the home’s purchase price**.
As long as you or your heirs own your home, the policy continues to protect your **property rights**.

Homeowners insurance and warranties protect the **structure** and **belongings**.  
Only owner’s title insurance protects your **legal ownership**.
More than **80% of homebuyers in the U.S.** choose to get owner’s title insurance every year.

Owner's title insurance gives you confidence and protection.  
You can close knowing that you won’t inherit debts or legal issues tied to the property.

Email: info@alliedtitleandescrow.com  
3100 Clarendon Blvd, Ste 630, Arlington, VA 22201-5302  
Phone: 703-567-7933  
Website: www.alliedtitleandescrow.com

*This advertising is for informational purposes only.  
Actual coverages and your eligibility may vary by company and state.  
For exact terms, conditions, exclusions, and limitations,  
please contact a licensed title insurance company in your area.*

section: What are the differences between Delaware and Virginia?
content:
Delaware is an **attorney-only state**.  
This means an attorney must conduct the closing and handle all funds.  
We work closely with trusted attorneys in Delaware to ensure the process is  
as similar as possible to Allied’s full-service offerings in non-attorney states  
like Virginia.

section: What is Allied's role in Delaware?
content:
- We issue the title policy for the closing attorney.  
- We offer guidance on title issues.  
- We can assist with logistics or services, as requested by the attorney.

section: What is the attorney’s role in Delaware?
content: - The attorney handles all **escrows** and **disbursements**.

section: Can Allied hold my EMD (Earnest Money Deposit)?
content:
Yes, absolutely!  
You can submit your EMD using the following options:
1. Through the **Earnnest** mobile app  
2. Wire transfer from your bank  
3. Overnight a check to one of our offices  
Once we receive the funds, Allied will transfer them to the closing attorney.

section: Can I reach out to Allied about my closing?
content:
Yes!  
We’re happy to assist with any communication between you and  
the attorney handling your closing.

section: Can I use Qualia to access my closing?
content:
Only if the **attorney** handling the closing also uses Qualia.  
Please note:  
Our Qualia system is set up differently for DE files than for VA files.  
You will not be able to access the DE file in our system.

section: Your Trusted Partner from Contract to Closing
content: Welcome! If you're considering making an offer on this home, here's what happens next — and how Allied Title & Escrow will be with you every step of the way.

- Order a title search  
- Prepare legal documents  
- Coordinate with your agent and lender  
- Ensure your ownership is clear and protected  
- Provide a final settlement statement for review  
- Schedule your closing (in-office or mobile)  
- Answer any last-minute questions  
- ...and anything else you might need!
Your agent will send your contract directly to Allied Title & Escrow. That's when our team jumps into action.
You'll be introduced to your dedicated Processor, your go-to contact from now until you get your keys.

We'll send secure instructions on how to send your EMD.  
We'll hold it safely in escrow and apply it toward your closing costs when you finalize your purchase.

section: WORKING WITH ALLIED TITLE: WEST VIRGINIA

content:
- West Virginia is an attorney-only state. This means that an attorney must conduct the closing and handle all funds.
- We work closely with trusted attorneys in WV to ensure that the process for you and your clients is as similar to Allied's full-service offerings in non-attorney states as possible.

section: What is Allied's role in WV?
content:
- We issue the title policy for the closing attorney and offer guidance on title issues.
- We can also assist with any logistics or services as they request.

section: What is the attorney's role in WV?
content: - The attorney handles the closing, communicating with lenders, agents, and clients, and handling the escrows and disbursements.

- Absolutely!
- EMD submission options include:
- Using the Earnnest mobile app
- Wiring to us from your bank
- Overnighting a check to one of our offices
- Once the funds hit our account, we will transfer the funds to your closing attorney.

section: Can I reach out to Allied about my closing?
content:
- Absolutely!
- We will be happy to help out with any communication between you and the attorney handling the closing.

section: Can I use Qualia to access my closing?
content:
- Only if the attorney handling the closing uses Qualia.
- Our Qualia is set up differently to handle WV files than it is for VA files, so you will not be able to access our Qualia file.

section: FOR HOMEBUYERS: A GUIDE TO TITLE INSURANCE

content: Title is your ownership right to your property.
No homebuyer wants to inherit existing debts or legal issues that could interfere with their property rights in the future. Clear title allows you to use or modify your property.
Your title professional has your back. They sweat the small stuff so you don't have to, giving you peace of mind.

Title insurance professionals examine or research public records to see if there are any problems or defects that could cause you legal issues. They may also manage the closing process.  
The title professional ensures the title search is completed, writes the title insurance policy and works to reduce your risk of ownership issues in the future.

A title search is an early step in the home buying process to uncover issues that could limit your rights to the property.  
If a title issue is discovered, most often your title professional will take care of it without you even knowing.  
After the title problem is fixed, you are able to purchase owner's title insurance.  
The title search protects you from unknowingly inheriting a previous owner's debts, legal obligations or other title problems.

There are two different types of title insurance: the owner's policy and the lender's policy.
- The **owner's policy** is purchased by you, the homebuyer. While it is your choice, purchasing an owner’s title insurance policy is the best way to protect your property rights.
- The **lender's policy** is usually paid for by you or the seller. It is almost always required by the lender and only protects the lender's interest.
Sometimes undiscoverable defects can come up after the title search. Title issues may include forgery, fraud or clerical errors.  
Owner's title insurance is the best way to protect yourself from losing your property.  
Every year, the vast majority of homebuyers in America elect to protect the largest investment of their lives, and purchase owner's title insurance.  
Owner's title insurance protects your interests after you purchase your home.

Closing is the final step in executing the home buying transition.  
It is the process that allows the transfer of ownership to occur.  
Upon completion of the closing process, you get the keys to your home!

This advertising is for informational purposes only. Actual coverages and your eligibility may vary by company and state.  
For exact terms, conditions, exclusions, eligibility, and limitations, please contact a title insurance company authorized to do business in your location.
For more information about owner's title insurance, contact info@alliedtitleandescrow.com  
Allied Title & Escrow II  
3100 Clarendon Blvd, Ste 630, Arlington, VA 22201-5302  
P.703-567-7933  
www.alliedtitleandescrow.com

**Standard coverage** protects against prior covered matters, such as:
- Someone claiming an ownership interest in your title
- Leases, contracts, or options affecting your title
- Someone claiming to have rights affecting your title due to forgery or impersonation
- Someone having a right to limit your use of the land
- Unmarketability of your Title
- A defective Title
**Enhanced coverage** includes all the risks within the standard policy as well as additional including:
- Inflation: your policy will increase 10% a year for 5 years
- Zoning violations
- Subdivision law violations
- Improvements that encroach into an easement
- Building permit violations
- Covenants, conditions, and restrictions
- Lack of vehicular and pedestrian access
- Supplemental assessments arising as a result of construction or a transfer prior to the policy date
- Damage to your house caused from someone with easement rights
- Someone refuses to buy your land because your neighbor's structures are on your land
- Your house or lawn and trees are being damaged by someone with rights to dig a well or mine
*Some coverages are subject to deductibles and liability caps*

section: HOW MUCH DOES TITLE INSURANCE COST?
content: The single premium is directly related to the value of your home. Typically, it is less expensive than your annual auto insurance. It is a one-time-only expense, paid when you purchase your home, yet it continues to provide complete coverage for as long as you or your heirs own the property.

section: COVERAGE COMPARISON OF STANDARD ALTA OWNER'S POLICY AND HOMEOWNER'S ENHANCED OWNER'S POLICY
content:
| Coverage Description                                                                                                          | Standard | Enhanced |
|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------|----------|
| Title to the estate or interest described in Schedule A being vested other than as stated therein                             | YES      | YES      |
| Any defect in or lien or encumbrance on the title                                                                              | YES      | YES      |
| Unmarketability of the title                                                                                                   | YES      | YES      |
| Lack of right of access to and from the land                                                                                   | YES      | YES      |
| You do not have both actual vehicular and pedestrian access to and from the land based upon a legal right                     | NO       | YES      |
| You are forced to correct or remove an existing violation of any covenant, condition or restriction affecting the land         | NO*      | YES      |
| You are unable to obtain a building permit; you are required to correct/remove the violation; or lose contracts/loans due to subdivision violation | NO* | YES |
| You are forced to remove/remedy existing structures (excluding boundary walls/fences) due to lack of a building permit        | NO*      | YES+     |
| You are forced to remove/remedy structures due to zoning violations                                                            | NO*      | YES+     |
| You cannot use the land for single-family residence due to zoning laws                                                         | NO*      | YES      |
| You are forced to remove your structures due to encroachment onto your neighbor's land                                         | YES      | YES+     |
| Contracts/loans are refused due to your neighbor's structures encroaching onto your land                                       | YES      | YES      |
| You are forced to remove structures that encroach onto an easement or building set-back line                                   | YES      | YES      |
| Structures are damaged due to exercise of easement rights                                                                      | YES      | YES      |
| Improvements (lawns, trees) are damaged due to future mineral/water/substance extraction rights                                | NO       | YES      |
| Someone enforces a discriminatory covenant/restriction (race, religion, etc.)                                                  | NO*      | YES      |
| Supplemental real estate taxes assessed before policy date due to construction or ownership change                            | NO       | YES      |
| Your neighbor builds structures post-policy date that encroach onto your land                                                  | NO       | YES      |
| The residence is not located on the land at the policy date                                                                    | NO       | YES      |
| Policy map does not match the public records location of the land                                                              | NO       | YES      |

section: Buyers Guide - Get Ready to Buy

content:
Take time to review your finances before the bank does. It will pay off!
- **Income:** Your lender will review employer information, time at job, and paystubs.
- **Credit Scores:** Request your full credit report (including your credit score) from Experian, Equifax, and TransUnion. Most companies will provide these once a year at no cost. Outside sources may not provide everything you need so, be sure to get them from the source.
- **Understand Your Credit Score:** Your credit score will be reported on as a number between 300 and 850. Your score will impact your qualification for a mortgage loan and your interest rate. Higher scores really do win here.
- **Check Your Balances:** You’ll need money for a down payment as well as insurance. If you can’t currently qualify for a loan, or will barely qualify, take steps to improve your credit score so you’ll be ready in the future.

If you do this now, it will save time in the future. You‘ll need to submit documentation to your lender and your title and settlement company. Better to plan ahead and avoid the last-minute scramble.
- The last two years’ tax returns  
- Pay stubs or proof of income (3 months)  
- Bank statements, brokerage, and investment account statements (last 12 months)  
- Proof of funds for down payment and closing  
- Unexpired Government Issued Photo Identification  
- If you are currently a renter you may need a letter of recommendation from a previous landlord

Make a list of your regular monthly expenses (credit card payments, student loans, car payments, and other recurring expenses, as well as average food, transportation, utilities, cell phone bills, etc.). When you see what you spend, you can set a realistic budget.

section: 4. Know Your DTI (Debt to Income Ratio)
content: Determine your DTI by taking your total monthly expenses and dividing that number by your total monthly income. This percentage helps determine how much you can afford to spend for a house. Your lender can provide a target. Rule of thumb: 43% is the number you’ll want to be below. At lower numbers, you may receive better terms and interest rates.

After assessing your finances and you believe you’re ready to buy, talk to a few lenders! Lenders will help you understand the types of mortgages you may be able to qualify for and can answer questions about terms, interest rates, and requirements for credit scores and DTI. Talk with a few and decide where you are comfortable.

You’ve gotten all of your questions answered and collected data. Did you find a lender you are comfortable with? Great! Ask the lender for a mortgage pre-approval. Pre-approval is not a guarantee that you’ll get a loan; and it does not commit you as the buyer. It’s a statement that you’re financially qualified to receive one, based on a preliminary examination of your finances. This will also give you a maximum loan amount, so you know what you can afford to spend. It’s a great sign for your agent and the home seller that you are ready and able to buy.

When it’s time to get serious, you’ll want an experienced real estate agent. Agents can provide valuable information on neighborhoods, schools, and have valuable insights including market conditions, comparable sales, and time on market. You’ll be happy to have an agent to negotiate on your behalf, prepare your offer, and help work through any issues that might arise.

Before you start looking, complete the Find Your Ideal Home Checklist to determine your priorities before you shop. This will help your agent recommend great options! Keeping your priorities top of mind may help you quickly eliminate the homes that aren’t right and help narrow down your list. Use the Home Evaluation Checklist to note each home’s features, be sure to capture plenty of details and take pictures! Keep your deadlines flagged on your calendar.

Found the perfect home? Your agent can help you make an offer as well as recommend contingency clauses, conditions, closing dates, and more. Your agent can also offer suggestions for termite/pest inspectors and a home inspector who will look for hidden structural or functional problems with the house.

section: 10. Contact Allied Title for Your Title & Escrow Needs
content: When you are making an offer, be sure to let your real estate agent know that you’ll be working with Allied Title for your title search and closing. Your agent will put the correct information on the ratified contract. Your processing team will work to coordinate all the details of your closing. Your settlement agent will explain the process and manage all of your documents through a secure portal. Allied will expertly conduct your title search and guide you through the title insurance options.
Once your offer has been approved, it’s time to call your lender to get started on the mortgage application.

Allied Title offers closing flexibility so that you can choose the closing that you are most comfortable with. Your settlement agent will provide a thorough explanation on payments and closing costs, insurance, and other information you’ll need so that as soon as everything is finalized, you’ll have the keys to your new home.
(via Zoccam)

1. Once logged in, click the “Earnest Money” box.
2. In the top search bar, type in “Allied” and select the “Allied” icon.
3. Select “OK” on the confirmation.  
*It is okay if it says "Allied Title Partners" in the confirmation.*
4. Select the appropriate Allied entity icon:  
- Allied Title Partners  
- Allied Title Texas  
- Allied Commercial Ventures  
*(Use the one that matches your transaction.)*
5. Enter the property address, check amount, and all other requested information on screen.

content:
- Select the “Paper Check” option  
- Take a scan or photo of your check  
- Press “Continue” and send

section: IF YOU DO NOT HAVE A PAPER CHECK:
content:
- Select the “Create” option  
- Log into your bank using your bank’s secure login  
- Pick the account you want the check created from  
- Sign in the white box as you would a physical check  
- Press “Continue” and send

ACH – YOUR VIRTUAL COURIER  
Support@Zoccam.com

section: Notice of Availability of Owner’s Title Insurance

content:
Virginia Code §38.2-4616 requires purchasers of residential real estate to designate in writing whether or not they wish to purchase Owner’s Title Insurance. Title insurance protects against the hidden hazards of real estate ownership.
You are *not* required to purchase title insurance to protect yourself as a purchaser. However, your lender **does** require title insurance to protect their collateral.
- **Lender’s Policy:** Protects the lender if you default on your loan and there are title issues during foreclosure. This policy **does not** protect you as the owner.

- Protects you from hidden title issues including:
- Hidden liens
- Forgeries
- Unreported tax bills
- Undisclosed claims to ownership or usage
- Covers legal fees to defend your rights to the property.
- Coverage extends even after the property is sold.
- Paid once at settlement — **no annual premiums**.

- May be filed by those who performed unpaid work or supplied unpaid materials to improve the property.
- Common in new construction or properties recently renovated.
- Liens can be filed up to **121 days after work is completed**.
- Title insurance may protect against these liens **if**:
- The seller provides affidavits, lien waivers, or receipts as required in the title commitment.
- Does **not** cover value of improvements made after the policy date.
- Coverage applies only to work completed **on or before** the date of the policy.

- Costs approximately **20% more** than the standard policy.
- Includes additional coverages such as:
- **Inflation rider**: Increases coverage by **10% per year** for the first 5 years (up to 150% total).
- For more information:  
http://www.oldrepublictitle.com/orstarslink/brochures/Enhanced%20Homeowner%20Policy%20of%20Title%20Insurance.pdf

- If you provide a copy of the current Owner’s title policy (your own or the seller’s) and it is **less than 10 years old**, you may be eligible for a **reissue credit** — a reduced price on the new policy.

- I want to purchase an Owner’s Title Policy.
- I want to purchase an enhanced Owner’s Title Policy.
- I do not want an Owner’s title policy.

section: Comparison: Standard vs. Homeowner’s (Enhanced) Title Insurance Policy
content: (Prepared August 2022 — © Old Republic Title | EZMO239)

3100 Clarendon Blvd, Suite 630  
Arlington, VA 22201  
www.alliedtitleandescrow.com

This brochure contains only a partial list of Covered Risks. All risks are subject to policy conditions, exclusions, and exceptions.  
The Homeowner's Policy covers only improved land with a one-to-four family residence, and each insured party must be a Natural Person or Estate Planning Entity.

section: COVERED RISKS — STANDARD POLICY VS. HOMEOWNER’S POLICY
content:
| Coverage Description | Standard | Homeowner’s | |----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------|-------------| | Someone else owns an interest in the title | YES | YES | | Someone else has rights affecting your title due to a lease, contract, option, or easement | | YES | | An existing defect, lien, or encumbrance not disclosed in the policy | YES | YES | | Refusal to perform a contract to purchase, lease, or make a mortgage on the land due to title defects | YES | YES* | | Improper execution, notarization, or recording of conveyance documents | YES | YES | | Neighbor’s structures encroach onto your land | NO | YES | | Your structures encroach onto a neighbor’s land | NO | YES | | Structures violate an easement or building setback | NO | YES | | You can't use an easement affecting your title | NO | YES | | No vehicular/pedestrian access to and from your land | NO | YES | | Neighbor builds structures (not boundary walls/fences) | NO | YES** | | Residence not located on the land per Schedule A | NO | YES | | Policy map does not show correct location per records | NO | YES | | Damage to improvements from subsurface development | NO | YES*** | | Loss of title due to covenant/restriction violation | NO | YES | | Violation of subdivision law causes:
- Inability to obtain building permit
- Required correction/removal
- Refusal to contract due to violation | NO | YES | | Ordered to remove structure for lack of building permit (excluding boundary walls/fences) | NO | YES | | Use of land as residence violates zoning laws | NO | YES | | Neighbor builds post-policy structures (not walls) | NO | YES** |

\* Includes post-policy coverage  
\** If the encroaching structures are boundary walls or fences, coverage is subject to a deductible and liability cap.  
\*** Coverage for subsurface damage is subject to a deductible and liability cap.
